definition:
An *endpoint* of a line segment $L$ is a point that belongs to the
boundary of $L$. Note that every line segment has two distinct
endpoints. For example, if $V$ is a vector space and $a,b \in V$ with
$b \neq 0$, then the endpoints of the line segment
$\displaystyle L = \{ a+tb : t\in[0,1]\}$ are $a$ and $a+b$.

(0,-0.5)(4,0.1) (0,0.06)[.]{} (0,0)(4,0) (0,0)(4,0) (0,-0.3)[$a$]{}
(4,-0.3)[$a+b$]{}

Note that the endpoints of the open line segment
$\displaystyle L=\{a+tb:t\in(0,1)\}$ are also $a$ and $a+b$.

(0,-0.5)(4,0.1) (0,0.06)[.]{} (0,0)(4,0) (0,-0.3)[$a$]{}
(4,-0.3)[$a+b$]{}
